title: Bartering restricted meal-vouchers
vignette: At a large food-aid festival, Person A holds vouchers that can only be used for approved food items. They offer their wine vouchers to Person B in exchange for an equal value of oil vouchers.

options.text: Swap is fine—an equal-value trade helps both.
Forbidden; the vouchers may only be given away, not traded.

title: Proposing with charity-designated calf
vignette: Someone tries to formalise an engagement by giving the other person an unblemished young calf that has been earmarked for donation to a community feeding programme.

options.text: Valid—the calf has monetary worth.
Invalid; items set aside for charity meals can’t be used for private deals.

title: Who keeps the hide after a charity-funded animal purchase?
vignette: Restricted meal vouchers are used to buy a steer for a group feast. After it’s eaten, the hide—worth more than the meat—remains. Who owns that hide?

options.text: Hide is ordinary property; the buyer keeps or sells it.
Hide is subject to the same restrictions as the meat; its value must also fund charitable meals.

title: Accidental non-food purchase with food vouchers
vignette: Someone mistakenly uses restricted vouchers to buy bottled water and table salt—items not on the approved list.

options.text: Purchase stands; just use the goods at the event anyway.
Deal is void; restore the vouchers’ purpose and dispose of the goods.

title: Buying real estate with restricted vouchers
vignette: A participant buys a small plot of land using vouchers meant only for ready-to-eat food at the festival.

options.text: Transaction valid—treat the land’s yield as future meal funding.
Prohibited; the buyer must earmark an equal sum of unrestricted cash for approved food purchases.

title: Using restricted olive oil as skin-care
vignette: A festival guest wonders whether their olive-oil ration—meant to be eaten—may be used as body lotion instead.

options.text: Yes; applying it counts as legitimate consumption.
No; the oil must be eaten, not applied externally.

title: Paying a porter with restricted produce
vignette: An owner asks a friend to haul restricted produce to the event zone. May the friend be rewarded with a share of that produce?

options.text: Yes; fair compensation for labour.
No; sharing the produce turns the vouchers into barter.

title: Buying from an uncertified vendor with restricted vouchers
vignette: A participant holding restricted food vouchers wants to buy produce from a street seller who isn’t certified to handle them.

options.text: Permitted; treat vouchers like cash and handle purity later.
Forbidden; risk of mishandling undermines the vouchers’ purpose.

title: Removing restricted food from the event zone
vignette: After the festival, a guest still has leftover figs inside the designated area. May they take them home?

options.text: Allowed; plan to bring them back later is enough.
Not allowed; once inside, the food is tied to the zone.

title: Cargo that merely passed through the festival zone
vignette: Crates of packaged grain briefly entered the event perimeter during transit and then left. Are the grains now bound by the zone’s consumption rules?

options.text: Yes; entry alone triggers the restriction.
No; owner can redeem and consume them anywhere.

title: Where to spend redemption cash for spoiled restricted food
vignette: Restricted fruit becomes spoiled. When vouchers are redeemed for cash, must that cash be spent inside the event zone or can it be used elsewhere?

options.text: Spend inside the zone unless spoilage happened outside.
Spend outside unless spoilage was minor and occurred inside.

title: Do empty containers inherit voucher restrictions?
vignette: A merchant sells sealed bottles of restricted wine. After pouring, do the empty bottles themselves become restricted assets?

options.text: Yes; container value is included.
No; only the contents are restricted.

title: Parent converting a child’s restricted produce
vignette: A father converts his young child’s restricted produce into cash vouchers. Must he add the usual 20 % premium that applies when redeeming one’s own produce?

options.text: Yes; treat the child’s assets like one’s own.
No; the surcharge applies only when redeeming your own produce.

title: Voucher swap to dodge the redemption surcharge
vignette: A participant trades several small restricted vouchers for one large voucher mainly to avoid paying the extra 20 % redemption premium.

options.text: Allowed; any exchange that lightens the load is valid.
Not allowed if the goal is to evade the surcharge.
